children.text: Hi, this is Jacob, when, today's date is July 8 2024, and I'm here in [COMMUNITY NAME] for an interview with the one of our community members. Before we begin, I'd like to get verbal consent for the form that we went over, could you please say I consent to being interviewed and audio recorded for this study?
I consent to being interviewed, and being recorded for this study.
Okay and to get started, can you tell me about how you came to live in this community?
I came to live in this community, because of, I knew I had a relative that lived out here. And I had visited him, and I liked the community. And that helped me make up my mind.
Okay, and could you tell me a little bit more about this community? How would you describe it to someone who doesn't live here?
Describe this community?
Yes. How would you describe this community to someone who does not live here.

Oh it's wonderful, wonderful place to be, the best thing about it is, is that it's a thriving community, but it has small town roots. Uh you feel like you're in a uh small town, but you're connected to the big cities and all the resources they have. But the thing about [COMMUNITY NAME] that's really, really good is as they uh have grown the city in the right ways to where their tax base, they have a lot of money coming in from the airport, and from the lake, and from a lot of these entertainment facilities, so their tax base is really large. And the community, the way they uh supply things for the people here that are taxpayers is they'll run a survey and they'll ask them, What do you want to see more of? And when they answer that survey, uh they've been able to give everybody everything they wanted. And uh it's just a really good community to be in, and uh the school systems are good, everything about it's good, it's got to be the best place to be.
What are the favorite? What are your favorite things about the community that you're glad that the city put their taxpayer dollars into?

I like uh the recreation center that they have, because they have a lot of senior programs. And now that I'm retired and older, I can take advantage of uh uh different programs that they put on, they have trips and stuff like that for seniors, and then they also have exercise classes. And they have uh a choir and other things, like just whatever you want to be interested in. And then they also have uh backing from the local hospitals, they come in and do clinics for people. And then they have events they put on that explains, you know, uh how retire - retirement and your savings and how you can best manage that yourself. Because a lot of people don't really understand, you know, how to manage their money and everything. So, being in the proximity to a lot of financial headquarters, you know, we have Fidelity and we have a lot of those different people. And uh they're in this area, and uh they are more than willing to come out and talk to people almost at any time. But that's one of some of the best things. But the other thing too is being connected to not only the the local arts, but the arts and the metroplex, so that you can travel and see concerts and just, they're just right down the street. And then the other thing is having the resources of the uh all the hospitals and medical care and stuff like that, I mean, it is outstanding. It really is. And uh I thought for a long time that I would want to retire and get out of the city and move to the country. But as I get older, I'm starting to realize that this is the best place to be.
That sounds amazing. And then how do you think this community has changed during your time living here?

It has changed from a kind of a small sleepy town to a uh uh more of a uh, you know, everything's new or being updated. And a lot of people are catching wind and trying to move move here. And it's kind of a destination, it's a place to be but a lot of people come here because they come and visit some of the uh like they close off Main Street and have arts festival or they'll have a wine festival and they've been doing this for 20 or 30 years, but people will come out for these festivals. And they like the town and they go you know, this is where I want to be and so that has caused the city to grow. But the the city has really taken care of the uh older residents of the town because they don't want to lose them. And so they they're given them a lot of tax incentives on their property and stuff where you don't get pushed out and that's what happens. In a lot of communities, you know, where people start moving and house prices start going up. And then the people that have been there for 20, 30 years, they, they kind of get pushed out, you know, but they don't want to do that here. They uh, they want to keep them as many of them as they can, because that's what makes this community what it is.
Yeah, sounds amazing. That sounds like a really great way to preserve the identity of the community, and keep it as like one unified.

It is. The other thing that's real helpful is the mayor has been mayor, almost consistently, except for maybe a couple of terms back in the 80s. And we've had the same mayor, who is a lifelong, [COMMUNITY NAME] residents, he was born and raised and grew up and went to school here and became mayor. And he's still mayor to today. And it seems like he's been married for forever. You know [CHUCKLES], but but he's, he does the right things. You know, he has community first and everything that he does, and I watch a lot of the council meetings and stuff online whenever they're having them. And uh I think that he is a big reason why everything is the way it is. Because a lot of people will developers want to move in here, and they just grabbed the land and, and try to build these, these condos and stuff like that. And he's like, no, no, no, no, you know, but let's put the brakes on that a little bit. You know, instead of building 30 houses, let's put five or 10, you know, and then more brick work, you know, so that so that it doesn't become just all brand new housing, they like to preserve a lot of the history, you know, and stuff like that. And that's a real good thing.

So do you think that the community has stayed or improved the way it has, because it has been able to consistently keep the same mayor who's lived there and knows the place and knows its residents and knows the culture?
Yes, I do. And the other thing, too, is I think they've tried to preserve history, they've gone out of their way to make a lot of the things like they were
[COUGHS]

And uh the the mayor remembers them personally, the way they were. So you know, he I mean, he knows all the farm houses around here, and he knows everything. And they, they do a good thing. But you have to understand uh that a lot of people don't they just think oh, that's a neat little artsy town and stuff like that. This is the oldest establishment in [NORTH TEXAS REGION COUNTY NAME]. This is the first this was before [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] or anything. When the Peters Colony came down here from Missouri, they settled the [COMMUNITY NAME] area, and the Indians signed treaties here. And, and I mean, this is this is really, this is a whole place. And to not recognize your uh history and everything in a place like this is uh it would be sad, but a lot of people that have lived here for many, many years, don't really realize exactly what the history is all about. And uh I just like to listen to people talk whenever they've been here for so long. It's it's just amazing to me, you know, the stories that they tell, kind of takes you back in time a little bit.
And that's definitely one of the strengths of the community. Can you tell me a little bit more about some other strengths that you might feel are within this community in particular, such
as other things? You said? What about?
So any, like, any other strengths that you feel are in this community in particular?
Any?
How do you feel like does this committee have strengths that you feel other cities might not have such as like?

Well, I think they've done everything right. And I think a lot of other communities have come over and looked at this for a model for their community, you know, like with, with some of the cities around here that are pretty robust, like [NEARBY COMMUNITY NAME] and [NEARBY COMMUNITY NAME] and [NEARBY COMMUNITY NAME], they didn't have a real downtown. Now [COMMUNITY NAME] always had kind of a little downtown area that kind of looks like something from Mayberry or something, you know. And if you went into [NEARBY COMMUNITY NAME] and stuff, you really didn't know where downtown was. I mean, there was some shops over here and stuff like that. And so a lot of them have kind of tried to recreate that whole downtown feeling so that they can have people come out on the Fourth of July and they have a meeting place where they can come and listen to music and bring their children and learn more about the city and everything. So I think that a lot of people have tried to duplicate what's been going done here. But the other thing is, is that with us having the tax base from the uh airport, and from uh Great Wolf Lodge and from Gaylord and all these hotels and everything the Other cities are more bedroom communities, they don't have that big a tax base. And so they're, they want to do this, but they don't really have the funds to do it with because I mean, yeah, you know, they've got a lot of houses and stuff like that. But those are more like bedroom communities. And so they struggle with trying to keep up with what's going, going on here.
And then, on the other hand, what would you say are some weaknesses of this community? What do you feel like could be improved?

What could be improved, I always think art can be improved, whether it be statues around the city, or or taking and restoring some of the old cabins and stuff like that. And I just think art is a big thing. And this community has drawn quite a few artists to it. And they have like up here at the Rec Center, they have uh, you know, have a display of somebody's works. And they actually put them up for sale and stuff like that. But the arts as far as the music, and uh you know, theater, I think theater is a wonderful thing. They have a theater, and then just everyday things that they do they uh, they have a thrift store that has a local thrift store that's run by the not necessarily the churches, but it's a nonprofit, but it's been in business as long as I've been here. And uh it's not like uh Dollar Tree or like Salvation Army, or it's not any of that kind of stuff.
[COUGH]

It's a local run, thing that self supports. So the [COMMUNITY NAME] citizens will give them things that they can sell to other [COMMUNITY NAME] people that are in need, and then maintain ourselves. So, you know, there's been a couple of times where buildings have opened up, and you know, Goodwill's, like, oh, we want to come in and go into business. And [COMMUNITY NAME] says, No, thank you. We have our own business, we have Grace and Grace is, is taken care of everything. And so they do go into other communities really easily, you know, because they're like, you know, we're Salvation Army or we're Goodwill, we help all this, you know, well, that's fine. But if all communities did what Grace did, we wouldn't need Salvation Army, we wouldn't need Goodwill. So they should look at that as a model thing that they can take to their communities and have their own uh place where people can come and get food, or they can, they can get funding from a church to stay in a motel for a week or something like that, you know, it's just, it's just a wonderful thing. But it, it's, it's, it can work within the community. But people have to come over here and see it to understand exactly what's going on with it. It's also funded by a lot of people do uh contributions to it, because the people are out here are real giving with what they do. But they want to give it to something that they can see that's going to benefit, you know, their community. It's hard to, you know, spend money in uh Goodwill and really see where it even goes, but,
Right.
with Grace, you know, that it's funding a food pantry. And then they have uh, they have a lot of things, they work with a lot of people.
That's amazing to hear. It sounds like a lot of the strength of the community come from its strong identity and culture and the type of people living here.

It does, it does, it draws good, smart people. And uh, you know, they handle everything the best way that they can, I can't really say that they haven't done uh. I mean, it's just been totally amazing to me. And I meet with a lot of people up here, this room is full of people every day that you know, we come up here and they they uh get the local restaurants will give you a $5 meal. But it's not that's not what it's all about. It's when you get older, you don't like being shut in. And so you get up here and you meet some of these people. And it's it's a wonderful thing, you know, you get out and plus, they had a lot of people that when they first started the program that were coming up here, and they would get meals and they take it to people that were like homebound, you know? Well, there's a service that they have that'll do that. It's called Meals on Wheels. Well, the Meals on Wheels, people said, you know, we'll bring meals to your house if you need that. And but people were still coming up here and getting their meals and leaving. And so they had to cut that off. And they said no. We want people to come up here and sit down and talk and enjoy an hour away from the house. So they can you know, converse mingle, whatever you call it, tell jokes, whatever you want to do, you know, we want people to get out and get together and I felt at first I thought you know, well that's kind of kind of hard because you're going to cut off a lot of people at home but they didn't do that they just offered them a different program. And uh they wanted to get as many people just to come up here and sit and do what they do. And they have a volunteer program that runs it, they have uh people that volunteer to make the desserts on a daily basis. And then they have uh young kids or teens or whatever, they come up here, uh service league and stuff like that. And they they bring in the whole community.
I was gonna ask, how's the food?

I think the food is good. And it's a good price. Because if you're single in a home, and you try to cook for yourself, a lot of times, uh you have to cook more than one and then so you end up eating the same thing for the next week. And then the other thing is, you end up throwing away uh food, because you have to buy it in quantity, you know, you can't just get like a third of a loaf of bread or something like that, you know, and if you're not eating, every day, uh a lot of it will spoil and go bad, and it's just kind of a so five bucks a day is is very good. It really is.
Yeah, sounds amazing.

And it's quality stuff. I mean, it's uh, they have fruits and vegetables, I mean, they, they pretty much look real close at what the uh dietary need is, for a lot of people, some people have restrictions, you know, and they try to address that as best they can.

And then you touched on this a little bit uh with this Meals on Wheels program. But can you tell me a little bit more about like the roles and relationships that you've had in the community over the years,

They uh, it's kind of the same thing they do here, this is the stuff that they serve here is kind of part of meals on wheels. And then Meals on Wheels, what they originally had was that they were delivering food to people that are homebound. And they would do that on a on a daily thing. And then they branched out and come into areas like this. And uh I think this whole thing is is probably run by Meals on Wheels, they have the most experience in this type of catering and stuff like that. But uh when I first started coming in, there was a lot of people would come in and sit down and you start talking to him, and then they'd get their meal, and they'd leave. And I mean, like half the room would leave. And it was just like, you know, it was and then they they decided, uh you know, we're not going to have people just coming in and picking up stuff and leaving with it, you know, they uh the people that they have here that work with the seniors are the most qualified people that could ever exist, they are the best, they must really do their work when they hire these people, because they are the best people for that job that you could ever meet. And when they promote, they promote from within a lot of the people that are here that are you know, they've been here for a year, one guy been here eight years and he's moving on to a better job within the rec, you know, so they uh, they get good people that are good at what they do. And bring them in and then grow them so that they can grow their career because nobody wants to be, you know, kind of stuck in one area you want to improve and then you want to move on and get a new challenge in your life and, and uh, you know, be uh contested a little bit, you know, where, where you have to develop, you know, you'll think and all this is hard and I can't do it. But then after a week or so you're like, hey, I kind of like this, you know, I like a challenge out there. So they're the people that are in charge of this rec and the way they do things. It's outstanding. It really is.
So would you agree that a lot of the relationships that you have built in this community are through that rec center program?
Yes.
Definitely. And then I like to talk about you as a retiree in [COMMUNITY NAME]. How you feel about that. Can you tell me a little bit more about what a typical day looks like for you?

What are they like is for me? Well, it it has changed in the last year before that. It was just kind of kind of slow and not really a whole lot going on. And then I was retired early so that I could be with my mother more because she was she's 104 right now. So at that time, I think she was 103 and I just wanted to spend more time with her. And so I retired early, a little earlier than 70. I think our what our 68 is when I retired like two years ago and when I retired I spent a lot of time with her, and uh she's a little bit less mobile now than what she was. And we did spend a lot of time together the first year. And then it's kind of dropping off a little bit because she's kind of losing her health and her hearing and her sight and stuff like that. But uh a lot of when I first retired us a lot of that revolve around her, and asking her questions about her childhood, and our relatives, and trying to get all that stuff lined up. And then eh she was in an apartment living by herself. And so I can go over there and visit her while she moved out of our apartment, because she was kind of getting to where she needed somebody to be around her all the time. So my sister and brother both have room in their houses. And so she spends her time at both locations. So now she's not only with me, but she's with my sisters part time, and she's with my brother part time. But after that dropped off, I mean, we had a lot of discussions, and she had asked me, you know, what do you do, and I told her, Well, they've got this program at the Senior Center, she goes, "Man, if I had that I'd be done on top of that", you know, she's said, "That's a deal." She said, "$5 for a meal, and then get to talk with people." She goes, "I bet you start going to that, I bet you meet some people that you really like." And uh Mom was right again. And the thing is, I just, if I didn't have something like that to do, besides hanging out with the guys down here and working once a week, or maybe once every two weeks, uh it gets me up and gets me go on, I've got something to do, I gotta go to the Rec and eat lunch. And then after that, I've met some people. And I'm like, you want to go down to a park and walk around, or you want to go down into a mall or do some shopping or something like that. So I've met a lot of people and it gets you going. And uh it's like that first task of the day, even though it's around noon, you know, I get up, I get ready, or go to lunch. And then from there, go to a movie or, or make plans for that evening, or just meet up with people.
So just like those little things that get you out of house and it gets the snowball rolling,

It does get you going. And that's the way things should work those when you get up in the morning, you should complete your task and and then start going about your day never know really what's going to be in line. But once you get that first task done, and then the other ones will fall in right behind it because you're already awake and dressed and ready to go. [CHUCKLES] I mean, it's it's it keeps a should've listen to my mom earlier, every time she tells me stuff that I need to do. And I don't do it. I probably miss out because she knows, you know, but
A lot of wisdom comes at that age.
Mom's right. I'll tell you what, she's right.
Yeah, moms are always right. Can you tell me a little bit more about? What do you feel like it means to be a retiree in this community?

I feel pretty respected. Uh I have gone through a lot in my life. And uh I do tell a lot of stories. And I really try not to hold back, you know, and uh there's some things I did that I'm not proud of. And then there's some things that uh that I just think are just neat stuff that happened along the way. And I just want other people to hear it and see what they say. And their reaction is is is. Some of the stories are really good. And some of them are kind of a little bit risque, I guess you could say, but you know, I don't want to, I don't want to beat around the bush. I just like to tell the stories as they happen, you know, and uh I'll tell people those stories, and they kind of look at me kind of like, Man, you've had a wild life, you know, and I was like, yeah, that's been fun. You know, that's really the way that I've always lived it and the way I partake on it, but uh I don't know if I fit in so much with the older people. But I think I fit in with people. I think that uh I like being around people. I like meeting people and being invited to have a conversation with people. When I worked customer service before our retired, it was going out and working on computers at people's houses and businesses. And the best part I liked about it was people. I mean, I could fix equipment all day long. That was no big deal. But I just thought it was a unique opportunity that every time somebody called you and wanted you to come fix up, you got to you got to meet somebody new, you know, and uh a friend to me is just somebody I've never met, you know, I mean, I just I just love that whole idea of it. And the other part about is is it's interesting as heck to be able to have people you know, what are you do here at this building, you know,
[COUGHS]

I mean, what do y'all do? What do y'all make? You know, and, and they'll tell you all about it. People are more than willing to open up to you. But sometimes I think people kind of kind of got a look at me as a, I don't know, pretty rough on some edges. But I think it's a lot of fun. I think laughter is the best cure. You know. And sometimes it's hard to make people laugh. But if you keep trying, it'll happen. [LAUGHS]
It's amazing mindset to have. And I mean, can you just tell me one of the most memorable or one of your favorite memories in this community?

Favorite, favorite memories? Well, you know, there's been a lot, I don't know what would be favorite ones. I think. When I first moved out here, we moved out here because we really enjoyed the lake. And we bought a boat. And uh I had uh was hooked up with a girl and we later got married, and she had a child from a previous marriage. And uh he was uh real young as four or five years old when we moved out here, and uh we just enjoyed going to the lake and camping. We went camping every weekend, and we had friends that would meet up and camp with and, and we did everything revolved around being in the water. And on the boats. I mean, we go down to the Brazos River and stuff like that, but, but initially, we came out here so that we could be close to the lake. Because if you live in a town and [NEARBY COMMUNITY NAME] or whatever, and you got to pack up all your boat, and your camping supplies, and everything, and then go to the lake and get gas and ice and all that stuff. And then you got to drag all that stuff back home 20, 30 miles back home to [NEARBY COMMUNITY NAME] or whatever, if you're in [COMMUNITY NAME]. I mean, you just got everything in the boat, you come home from work, you just jump in, and you're in the lake in 15 minutes. And so a lot of people didn't come out during the week, and we like to go out. Because we were big in the water skiing. We liked it when there wasn't a lot of people around. And so uh we'd go out during the week. And then on the weekends, we'd go camping, and instead of skiing so much. But uh we had a really good times this five or six year old kid turned out to be a really good water skier. And he was acting out in school because I guess I don't know being a stepchild or whatever and single not having brothers and sisters to compete with and everything and, and so I just kind of took him on under my sleeve, our own or my wing. And me and him we're going every weekend, we were going out to these tournaments, is can and meeting all these older guys. And when you you meet these guys, and they're like in their shorts down at the lake, they're just guys, and you're just talking skin and everything. And then later on. "So Michaels, where did you know that guy who was president of bank one?" And you're like, "Why then?" And then you know another guy, they say, "Oh, yeah, he's a pilot all of a 747 out of DFW." And I was like, "Really," and they're talking to my son, like they talked to me, you know, "Hey, man, you had a pretty good run today." And they're sitting over there chatting. And I'm like, you know, he doesn't understand that that's like the CEO of of Fidelity, you know. And so it kind of dropped all the borders, that you could meet people and be on their level. And they like they liked it that way. I mean, they didn't come in with a big chip on their shoulder or anything. Everybody was equal when they were down by the lake. But I think the time that I spent with him was well invested. He grew up to be a good kid, he did have some rough times. And he's, uh he's learned his lessons very well. And I'm really proud of the person that he became.

That's amazing to hear. It sounds like he had a really unique childhood, that not a lot of people get they kind of have that experience of meeting so many older folks and like being able to talk to them as if you're on the same level. Because normally when you're your child, you know, when you see adults they're, you view them as someone like it's a figure of authority. So when you can't really kind of speak out to anything.

Oh, no, no, in fact, you know, one of the guys I just he was working at some uh big bank down there. And I told him one time I was talking to him, I said, Yeah, you know, we come in there and work on computers ever so often. He said, Well, next time you get down there, look me up. He said uh it. I said well, you know, I said uh "Your name is George." He said "yeah, George" and so "What's your last name?" He said "Barclay, George Barclay," and almost like, oh, okay, so about a week or so went by, and I went into the, the bank to work on the computer. And I had some time and I asked the guy behind the desk, I said, "Is George Berkeley, you know, if he works, here," he goes, "George Barclay." He said, we don't have anybody here by that name. You know, I said, "It's no big deal. He just told me he worked here." And then went and sat down. And then a guy walked over. And he said, "Now, are you talking about Mr. Barclay?" And I said, "Well, I call him George." He's had this uh, like, quarterly report in a magazine, full color magazine, and everything's for uh Texas, Federal Home Loan Bank, on the coffee table right in front of me. And he opened it up to the first page, and there was a full size picture of George. Yeah, I go that's him. They go, "Oh, that's the CEO, or whatever you want me to call him? And we'll have you go and meet with him?" And I was like, No, I don't think so [CHUCKLES]. So the next time I saw him, he was having a party out at his house. And he invited us out. And it was overlooking some big horse farm and stuff like that. And he was just as neat a guy you can imagine. But, you know, he drove a little Subaru. And he really wasn't a real flashy guy, or anything. And it was it was pretty unique how, how people are. So they're in positions like that. But yet, they're, they're so easy to talk to and

Yeah really humanizes. You know, those kinds of people, but like, you're like, oh, "I can, I would never be able to meet the CEO of that company is just some sort of figure at the very top" that you're like, that's not a real person. And then you meet them in real life. And it's like, "Oh, my God," like, they're just a normal guy.

Yeah, he had some, some of them carry an air about them, you know, I worked. When I first was thinking about retirement, I kind of took a part time job at Home Depot, and we had guys that came in there. There were like, football and baseball stars and everything. And, and when they walked in, everybody's like, "ooh," and "aww" and all this kind of stuff, you know, and, and uh, you know, they're like, "You know who that is?" And I was like, "No, he look like a Harlem Globetrotter or something," you know, but
And then just moving on to like, to talk more about your retirement in this community? What aspects of it bringing the most joy and satisfaction?

I just like meeting people, I just think it's what's a wonderful thing. One of the things that I had suggested that ask every year they put out a survey and ask you, you know, how do you like things? How are things going? And what would you like to see added to it and everything? My only comment was, as I thought that they ought to do interviews with the elders of the community, which is what exactly was what you're doing, you know, and I said, you could just take someone, most of the people that are up here are widows, most of the husbands have died, and they're widows, but they have a story to tell, you know, and I would like to see it, that they get these stories before they're gone. You know, they, if they could get them just to agree to a question and answer type thing and, and just make it as casual as possible. But then the record that for all everyone to hear from here on out, and they don't have to be long, punctual stories, it can be just funny things that happen to them or things that they will remember, just little things, because you know that I think it'd be a lot of fun, because I mean, everybody has something unique about and then the other thing to do would be the interaction from the other people, if you have them up in front of them, you know, people are like asking "I remember you" [LAUGHS], you know, to get them involved in it, too, because, you know, I think everybody would would be interested in hearing the, the history, and uh I think it should be preserved.
I know exactly what you mean, even myself, as I've gotten older, and I kind of see my parents is more just like normal type of people.
Mhm.

And then I asked them, that makes me more curious. Like, I asked them about questions in their childhood, like when they were in their 20s. Like, you know,"What kind of person were you in your 20s? What kind of crazy, crazy stuff where were you doing? Because I've only ever known you as my parent. I've never known you as the party animal you were in the 20s."

I think that's why I have so many uh crazy stories is people didn't uh uh. I was pretty wild. And you know, I had sleeping bag, I could sleep well on the side of the road. And I did this a number of times because I worked for an airline one time, and they would fly me out to the West Coast for free. And then I could hitchhike from like San Francisco down to uh Monterey, or, or Big Sur, or any of those kind of like hippie hangout type things. And uh I went all around the country hitchhiking, and uh I just don't remember ever having money. I just don't even remember buying anything. I just, I just, I don't even remember having a wallet. You know, people are like, oh, "Somebody could have, you know, took your money." And I said, "I don't think I had any money." You know, I mean what are you going to get out of somebody that doesn't have it. But I guess it was just those times where you just, uh you know, people would just help you out the best. I don't remember. You know, I don't remember being hungry. I don't remember being thirsty. I don't remember having money. But I just remember meeting a lot of very nice people. So I tried to walk out, so I just went out the door and started walking. And there was no sidewalks. And I was like, "Whoa, you know, there's a big road over there."
